title: 103_s513
content: The Act titled "Tobacco Consumption Reduction and Health Improvement Act of 1993" increases taxes on tobacco products. The "Tobacco Consumption Reduction and Health Improvement Act of 1993" raises taxes on cigars and cigarettes. For cigars, the tax rate is increased to $4.6875 per thousand, and for large cigars weighing more than 3 pounds per thousand, the tax is 50% of the selling price but not exceeding $120 per thousand. The tax rates on cigarettes, cigarette papers, and cigarette tubes are increased under the "Tobacco Consumption Reduction and Health Improvement Act of 1993". The new rates are $50 per thousand for cigarettes, 3.12 cents for cigarette papers, and 6.25 cents for cigarette tubes. The tax rates on various tobacco products were amended under the "Tobacco Consumption Reduction and Health Improvement Act of 1993". The new rates are $1.50 for snuff, 50 cents for chewing tobacco, and $2.8125 for pipe tobacco. The "Tobacco Consumption Reduction and Health Improvement Act of 1993" amended tax rates on tobacco products in the United States before January 1, 1994. Taxes were imposed on small and large cigars, small and large cigarettes based on weight and price. The tax rates on tobacco products were amended by the "Tobacco Consumption Reduction and Health Improvement Act of 1993" before January 1, 1994. Taxes were imposed on small and large cigars, small and large cigarettes based on weight and price. Cigarette papers are taxed at 2.37 cents for each 50 papers, while cigarette tubes are taxed at 4.75 cents for each 50 tubes. The tax rates on tobacco products were amended by the "Tobacco Consumption Reduction and Health Improvement Act of 1993" before January 1, 1994. Taxes were imposed on small and large cigars, small and large cigarettes based on weight and price. Cigarette papers are taxed at 2.37 cents for each 50 papers, while cigarette tubes are taxed at 4.75 cents for each 50 tubes. Snuff is taxed at $1.14 per pound, chewing tobacco at 38 cents per pound, and pipe tobacco at $2.1375 per pound. Liability for tax on tobacco products imposed by the "Tobacco Consumption Reduction and Health Improvement Act of 1993" requires payment by holders of specified products on January 1, 1994. The tax is due and payable on February 15, 1994, following the same method as taxes under section 5701 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Tobacco Consumption Reduction and Health Improvement Act of 1993" imposes taxes on tobacco products like cigars, cigarettes, snuff, chewing tobacco, and pipe tobacco. Retail stocks held on January 1, 1994, are exempt from these taxes. Foreign trade zones are also included in the regulations. The "Tobacco Consumption Reduction and Health Improvement Act of 1993" imposes taxes on tobacco products like cigars, cigarettes, snuff, chewing tobacco, and pipe tobacco. Foreign trade zones are exempt from these taxes for products entered after January 1, 1994. Cigars, cigarettes, snuff, chewing tobacco, and pipe tobacco entering the US from a foreign trade zone after January 1, 1994, are subject to taxes as if held for sale on January 1, 1994. The text discusses the taxation of tobacco products entering the US from a foreign trade zone after January 1, 1994. It mentions that these products will be treated as if held for sale on that date. Additionally, it establishes a Trust Fund related to this taxation. The text establishes a Health Reform Trust Fund under SEC. 9512. The Health Reform Trust Fund is created in the Treasury of the United States, consisting of appropriated amounts. The Secretary transfers an amount equivalent to the net revenue increase to the Trust Fund. Eighty percent of the Trust Fund amounts are available each fiscal year for uninsured persons. The Health Reform Trust Fund, created in the Treasury of the United States, consists of appropriated amounts. Twenty percent of the Trust Fund is available each fiscal year for health education, smoking cessation programs, and distribution to states reducing tobacco taxes due to federal excise tax increases. The Tobacco Consumption Reduction and Health Reform Act of 1993 includes a clerical amendment to the table of sections for subchapter A. The Tobacco Consumption Reduction and Health Reform Act of 1993 includes a provision for the Health Reform Trust Fund, with amendments effective for certain tobacco products removed after December 31, 1993.
